events.title: Fall of Constantinople
events.description: Ottoman forces led by Sultan Mehmed II captured Constantinople, marking the end of the Byzantine Empire.
events.significance: This event represents a major turning point in world history, effectively ending the Middle Ages and marking the rise of the Ottoman Empire as a dominant power.

events.title: The Restoration of the English Monarchy
events.description: King Charles II was restored to the throne of England, marking the end of the Commonwealth period.
events.significance: The Restoration restored the monarchy after the English Civil War and Interregnum, profoundly influencing the British political system and monarchy.

events.title: The Armory Show Opens in New York
events.description: The International Exhibition of Modern Art, known as the Armory Show, opened in New York City, introducing Americans to European avant-garde art.
events.significance: This event significantly influenced modern art in America, exposing the public to new styles such as Cubism and Fauvism.

events.title: Everest Conquered for the First Time
events.description: Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay became the first climbers confirmed to reach the summit of Mount Everest.
events.significance: This feat was a major milestone in human exploration and mountaineering, symbolizing human endurance and determination.

events.title: The Republic of Montenegro Declares Independence
events.description: Montenegro officially declared its independence from the State Union of Serbia and Montenegro, becoming a sovereign nation.
events.significance: This peaceful breakup marked the final dissolution of the former Yugoslavia's successor state, altering the political landscape of the Balkans.
